title.narrative: Namibia Food Insecurity 2019/2020

description.narrative: Start and End dates: 20th June 2019 - TBC Summary:Â On May 6, 2019, Dr Hage Geingob, President of the Republic of Namibia declared a state of emergency due to poor rainfall and the prevalent drought within the country. To complement this, the Namibia Red Cross Society, Spanish Red Cross and British Red Cross collaborated to support 599 HHs over a period of four months. Cash assistance has not been used as a standard response modality in Namibia but for this project the Government of Namibia has agreed that the NRCS could trial the distribution of cash among affected HHs and farmers.In October 2019, the government of Namibia extended the state of emergency and national disaster period by six months to March 2020Â stating that the number of people in need of aid had more than tripled to 900,000 (more than 30% of the population) Location: Sibbinda Constituency, Zambezi Region, Namibia Bens: Phase 1 = 599HHÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Phase 2 = additional 612HH = 1,211 HH Donor: None â€“ However Â£75K for Phase 1 and Â£200K for Phase 2 came from DF PNSs: Spanish Red Cross and German RC Budget: Phase 1 BRC sent Â£175K and Phase 2 BRC sent an additional 200KÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Q4 2019:Â In September 2019, additional funding provided by the German Red Cross and German Government expanded the intervention within the targeted communities registering an additional 612 households raising the total to 1,211 households. The intervention was later extended to March 2020 with additional cash distributions added in November, January, February and March. April 2020: Â Funds for a PMEAL training that had to be cancelled due to COVID19 and some extra funds from a favourable exchange rate are going to be used for COVID 19 response. Spanish report cross have agreed for us to extend this emergency till April 2020 with a final report in May 2020.Â

title.narrative: COVID-19 Outbreak

description.narrative: On 31 December 2019, WHO was alerted to several cases of pneumonia in Wuhan City, Hubei Province of China. This virus was later identified as a new virus and has been named â€œ2019-nCoV.â€ The new virus is a coronavirus, which is a family of viruses that include the common cold, and viruses such as SARS and MERS. On the 30th January 2020, Coronavirus was declared a public health emergency of international concern by WHO. On the 28th February 2020 the WHO upgraded the global risk from the coronavirus to "very high." On the 11th Feb the virus was officially named COVID-19: - The name is taken from the words "corona", "virus" and "disease", 2019 representing the year that it emerged. - The word coronavirus refers to the group of viruses it belongs to, rather than the latest strain. - The virus itself has been designated SARS-CoV-2 by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses. On the 11th March the coronavirus outbreak was labelled a pandemic by WHO.

title.narrative: Iraq Programming

description.narrative: The French Red Cross (FRC) has been operational in Northern Iraq alongside the Iraqi Red Crescent (IRCS) since 2013, especially in Dohuk, Ninewah and Erbil governorates so far. Focused first on the influx of Syrian refugees, then on the IDP crisis and the challenging displacements and returns of population, FRC provides assistance in a range of sectors including WASH, livelihoods, education, shelter and relief in cooperation with the IRCS Current programming includes WASH, Livelihoods, Education and Psychosocial Support and Disasters Preparedness and Disasters Reduction thematic. Mainstreaming of the capacity building of the Iraqi Red Crescent (IRCS) in FRCâ€™s daily work is also a main priority. Sinjar District in Northern Iraq is still facing a number of challenges following the liberation in 2015 from ISIS, with a large amount of the population still being displaced within Iraq. The current outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and the accompanying lockdowns and curfews have put additional economic pressure on the population. In recent months, an increase in returns of IDPs to Sinjar could be observed, 14,704 individuals (2,711 families) have arrived between 8 June and 12 August 2020 (IOM data). With much of the houses, farms, and key infrastructure destroyed or still contaminated with unexploded ordinance, people returning are facing difficulties re-establishing their livelihoods.Present in Sinjar since 2016, FRC has visited several of the affected communities currently receiving returnees in August 2020, and in addition has collected information from secondary sources such as UNHCR, district representatives, and local NGOs. All sources confirm water supply as one of the key needs.Â Â BRC completed an evaluation of one of the programmes; Cash-For-Work (CFW) through WASH project in Iraq in 2019 and found the cash-based component of the project was successful. The evaluation report recommended implementing remaining Iraq appeal funds in Sinjar to build on the previous WaSH and CFW implemented in that area and to support people, including SGBV survivors, impacted by displacement and protracted conflict.Â Therefore, the Iraq WaSH and MPCA project in Sinjar has two key areas of work: firstly the rehabilitation of two boreholes for recently returned IDPs to stop the dependence on water trucking. Secondly a one-off MPCA for 115 HHs and 50 GBV survivor households.Â Â Â Â Â

title.narrative: Eswatini Silele Community Project

title.narrative: Ethiopia, Sudan and Djibouti population movement 2020/2021

description.narrative: Wednesday 4th November 2020, Ethiopian Prime Minister confirmed a state of emergency and launched a military operation for 6 months in the Tigray region agaisnt The Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) - a historically powerful political party.Â IFRC have approved DREFs for specific responses in Ethiopia and Sudan and there is potential for an Emergency AppealÂ During the recent years, parts of Ethiopia, Sudan and Djibouti have been affected by the compounded effects of climatic shocks (leading to droughts and floods, the locust infestation and disease outbreaks) and the spread of COVID-19, impacting peopleÂ´s coping capacities. The eruption of armed violence in Tigray in early November has triggered a humanitarian crisis while exacerbating other underlying vulnerabilities.Â Â Â As leading humanitarian actors and front-line responders, often where others do not have access, the components of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement are present in all three countries and coordinate closely to respond to critical needs of people affected by multiple vulnerabilities, particularly in the fields of protection, health, psychosocial support (PSS), restoring family links (RFL), economic security and water and sanitation, The IFRC and the ICRC have launched coordinated appeals, seeking a total of CHF 47 million to scale up humanitarian activities and strengthen coordination systems in a multi-country approach

BRC contribution to SRCS Protection and PFA trained-volunteers, to support the Ethiopia Population Movement emergency operations and the influx of refugees into Eastern Sudan. Payment via Danish RC and to bridge the gap before the Â£1mill PPL programme starts in 2021Â
BRC payment of Â£150,000 to IFRC Emergency Appeal for Ethiopia, Sudan and Djibouti complex crisisÂ
Payment to IFRC to cover 3 months of the Ethiopia Ops Manager for the Population Movement EmergencyÂ

title.narrative: Kenya Locusts, Floods & COVID 2020

description.narrative: Situation: in addition to the COVID outbreak, there is ongoing flooding and locust swarms. Flooding is widespread, affecting 43 counties. KRCS is doing a Locust Impact assessment funded by FAO and there is an inter-agency floods assessment being done. IFRC response: There is an open floods EA, Locust EA covering Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia, Uganda and South Sudan (launched 17/04/2020, for 1.8mill CHF, 9 months) and of course COVID country plan and regional COVID EPoA.Â BRC support: Â£300k DF pledge to support KRCS bi-laterally in the response to these emergencies. Many of the same communities are being affected simultaneously by all three. In-line with conversations happening at different forums, there is a need for us to support partners integrated responses as much as possible. It does not make sense operationally and in terms of value for money to separately support 3 different IFRC EAs and with KRCS a long term partner, bi-lateral support is the best option. How KRCS will use the funds: Plan with KRCS DM team. The proposal is to support communities with multi-purpose cash, to 2145 HH over 3 months (July-Sept 2020), with risk communication (consolidated messaging of the various risks.) The cash intervention will be an expansion of an existing programme, so everything is already in place.

title.narrative: Beirut explosion 2020

description.narrative: The explosion at the Port of Beirut at 6:10pm on Tuesday 4th August 2020 caused extensive damage, loss of life and has impacted hundreds of thousands of people in Beirut. As of 25th September, over 190 people are reported to have died, with more than 6,500 people injured. The Government of Lebanon estimates that around 300,000 people were made homeless following the Beirut Port explosion and up to 40,000 buildings sustained damage. The explosion occurred while Lebanon faces a deep economic and political crisis, and rising COVID-19 cases. Protests against the Lebanese government have been taking place for months in Beirut prompting the Government to step down on 10 August 2020. Poverty has risen in recent months; 2.7 million residents are now poor and 1.1. million are extremely poor. The Lebanese Red Cross immediately mobilized its teams and assets to respond to the blast. They have launched a one-year Response Plan appealing for $125 million to respond to the needs of those affected by the multiple overlapping shocks faced by many in Lebanon during 2020.

title.narrative: DM and WASH support to communities in Yemen

description.narrative: This intervention builds on EnhancedÂ Vulnerability and Capacity Assessments (EVCA) conducted as part of the previous BRC-supported DM project in Yemen.Â Using theÂ recommendations from theÂ EVCAâ€™sÂ as a basis,Â theÂ project for 2020Â will focus onÂ buildingÂ disaster risk reduction throughÂ twoÂ approaches:Â 1)Â community-basedÂ preparednessÂ (including supporting the NS to efficiently and effectively deliver these services)Â 2)Â riskÂ mitigationÂ and DRRÂ measuresÂ particularly focused onÂ WASH support.Â These areas of focus aim to ensure the recommendationsÂ specifically identifiedÂ by the communitiesÂ are metÂ toÂ help reduce their vulnerabilityÂ and meet their immediate needs.Â The overall goal is toÂ Â reduceÂ theÂ vulnerability of communities in Yemen to the effects ofÂ the ongoing humanitarian crisis, exacerbated by recurrentÂ naturalÂ andÂ man-madeÂ hazards. As part of this project, contingency planning and EWS will be established, essential relief material prepositioned, DRR activities will be implemented and access to water ensured for 16 communities across 4 governorates (Shabwa, Al Mahra, Amran, Dhamar).Â Taking into consideration the current pandemic of COVID-19, the programme will also include risk communication and awareness sessions on hygiene promotion.

First payment towards the DM and WASH project with IFRC and YRCS. As per the GAD, the grant will be transfered in two tranches: - CHF 190,843 at the begining of the project - CHF 90,574 after 6 months (01.01.2021) Â

title.narrative: Myanmar Northern Rakhine project

description.narrative: The project will address the primary and secondary impact of Covid-19 in Maungdaw and Minbya township in Rakhine, supporting the implementation of preventative measures, increasing awareness and addressing basic needs of vulnerable communities in two townships in Rakhine. In addition, the project aims to enhance the capacity of MRCSâ€™ township branches and strengthen linkages between the branch and the network of community volunteers, which are critical to the success of the project. Â In the short term, 5 villages will be able to successfully form community volunteer groups which fosters sustained linkages with the Township branch. In the long term, it is expected that these linkages will be mobilised to support a community led resilience building, as discussed in the Lessons section above. This approach will be integrated into the Covid-19 recovery phase and addressing the secondary impacts of Covid-19. The project includes: 1) COVID awareness sessions, through the approach of RCCE, MRCS will conduct COVID-19 awareness sessio in the targeted communities. 2) Community level cloth mask making, community level volunteers will be organised and trained to undertake community level cloth mask making activities in selected villages. Community level tailors will be enaged in the process pf producing mask under tehcnial supervision and guidance of MRCS. 3) Community level hand soap making, the village colunteer groups thorugh active participation of community members will undertake hand wash soap making acvities and the liquid soap will be distributed among village schools and other common community meeting places, including monastaries and community quarantie facilities within villages. 4) Community quarantine facility management support will focus on supporting community quarantine facilities managed by village admistration and committees prioritizing required materials based on the needs identified such as water storage, batteries for electricity and other basic supplies. 5) Cssh for basic needs to the most vulnerable people undergoing community quarantine in targeted communities with one-time cash transfer of MMK 35,000 meeting basic needs of people 6) Training and buioding capacity of MRCS branch and red cross volunteers to support the COVID response Â Â Â Â Â
M2010027 - BRC to pay IFRC for supporting Myanmar Northern Rakhine Project

title.narrative: Integrating TB and malaria services into Maternal and Neonatal Child Health

description.narrative:
In Ethiopia, approximately 68% of the population is at risk of malaria with nearly a million people detected annually. The TB incidence in 2018 was 151 per 100,000, with yearly detection exceeding 110,000. More than three million women give birth annually in Ethiopia and are equally or more at risk of acquiring malaria or TB. The aforementioned complexities of these diseases in maternal and child health apply to all parts of Ethiopia. However, the four regions of Afar, Benishangul-Gumuz, Gambella, and Somali are more likely to be affected due to relatively weak health systems and poor health seeking behaviours. These regions have vulnerable communities due to their pastoralist and semi pastoralist lifestyles and are also affected by calamities such as droughts and disease outbreaks.
Amref operates in these areas to mainly implement Reproductive Maternal Neonatal and Child Health programs. Through an existing Amref-led Transform HDR project, Amref will contribute towards tackling these challenges. The existing project aims to increase health access and address vulnerable communities. The first intermediate result of Transform HDR focusses on access to healthcare, mainly maternal and child health (MCH) and malaria, in the developing regional states of Afar, Benishangul-Gumuz, Gambella and Somali.
Through this programme, Amref will continue to address the gaps in malaria and TB in mothers and children, in order to build upon current achievements and maximise impact. Additionally, to combat the detrimental effects of COVID-19, each activity will consider preventative measures such as physical distancing, hand hygiene and appropriate use of face masks.

The programme will train 320 health workers on malaria diagnosis/management, 375 health workers on TB diagnosis/management and 70 lab technicians on proper diagnosis and EQA mechanism. The project will also directly reach 72 health centres, 3 hospitals and 295 community health posts for EQAs/diagnosis quality assessments.

The programme’s overall objective is to improve prevention, detection, diagnosis and management of TB and malaria among mothers and children in developing regional states of Ethiopia. Specific objectives are: (1) Improve the capacity of frontline health workers for effective diagnosis, referrals and treatment of TB and malaria among women and children by integrating with MCH activities; (2) External Quality Assurance (EQA) on laboratory services for malaria, TB and lab services for ANC; (3) Knowledge management to improve integrated programming to strengthen PHC as a means to UHC. Project outcomes will be (1) 80% of targeted health workers can effectively diagnose and manage TB and malaria among ANC and under 5 clinic followers, (2) 95% EQA Concordance rate for malaria and TB diagnostics in over 80% of health facilities, and (3) 80% of data completeness from targeted health facilities

title.narrative: Stop the Spread COVID-19 in Amhara, Ethiopia

description.narrative: This project aims to train 8,000 health extension workers (HEWs) in the Amhara region through Amref's mobile digital training platform LEAP. The HEWs will be trained using a COVID-19 curriculum developed with the MoH focussing on key topics including community-based tracing, prevention and management of COVID-19, and measures to contain the spread.
This project is part of Amref's co-ordinated response to Stop the Spread and Flatten the Curve in 8 priority countries across Africa.
This project will be directly targeting 8,000 HEWs to gain knowledge that will indirectly benefit households in the Amhara region

title.narrative: Reproductive Health and Access to Water, Sanitation and Hygiene in Kajiado County, Kenya

description.narrative:
Kajiado County is a rural county in the south-east of Kenya, bordering Nairobi to the North, and Tanzania to the South. It is home to Maasai communities, including Nice Nailantei Leng’ete, Amref’s Global Ambassador to End Female Genital Mutilation or Cutting (FGM/C), who has been working for many years to reduce FGM/C across the region. Amref has been working in Kajiado County for 11 years. Over the last three years Amref, with funding from Stitching Ondersteuningsfonds Zorg Welzijn en Sport (ZWS), has been delivering the ARPWASH Model project in Kajiado. Through integrated Alternative Rites of Passage and WASH interventions, this project aimed to improve Sexual Reproductive Health Services and Rights (SRHR) among adolescent girls and women of reproductive age. The project will end in June 2020, having reached 27,691 people. As a result of the project 23 villages have been declared Open Defecation Free (ODF) communities and 2,725 adolescent girls were trained on SRHR, life skills, and hygiene, and graduated through Community-Led Alternative Rites of Passage (C-ARP) instead of going through FGM/C. A recent evaluation of Amref’s C-ARP programme in Kajiado County has shown that CL-ARP plays a decisive role in decreasing FGM/C, child, early and forced marriage. Since the programme started, FGM/C rates among girls in the region have declined by 24.2%, girls on average stayed in school for 2.5 years longer, and were more likely to delay marriage and childbirth, with teenage pregnancy declining by 6.3%. Women in Kajiado County bear the greatest burden when it comes to access to healthcare and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH). Women are at risk of complications from pregnancy and childbirth, early marriages, unwanted pregnancy, and FGM/C. There is also increasing evidence that the reproductive health of women and girls is disproportionately affected by lack of access to WASH services, due to biological and cultural factors. Integrating WASH practices into health service delivery in health facilities and improving access to WASH within communities has been shown to decrease both morbidity and mortality of women and girls. WASH interventions are cost effective and help to improve gender equality and human rights by giving women and girls more social freedom and safety and removing inequitable work burdens. The COVID-19 pandemic, and resulting movement restrictions and school closures, has disrupted access to critical Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) services and hampered authorities’ ability to respond to Gender Based Violence (GBV) and harmful practices like FGM/C, child, early and forced marriages and teenage pregnancies. Reports of these have risen over recent months and reduced physical interaction between health workers and community members has hampered the ability to track and monitor girls at risk of FGM/C enrolled on Amref’s C-ARP programme.
Amref's second phase of the ARPWASH model project to improve the health and well-being of women of reproductive age in Kajiado by integrating SRHR, C-ARP and WASH interventions. The second phase will address gaps that have been identified during Phase One, many of which have been exacerbated by Covid-19: 1. Lack of online Tracking/Monitoring tool for 2,725 girls reached through the C-ARP 2. At least 1,500 girls still at risk of FGMC, early marriage and unintended pregnancy 3. At least 3,000 people still not reached with clean water sanitation and hygiene 4. Seven villages (1,750 people) still practicing open defecation still practicing open defecation 5. Limited public health infection, prevention and control measures With funding from the Rabelais Trust, we propose to fill these gaps by: 1. Training 90 Community Health Workers (CHWs) through our Leap digital platform on infection prevention at community and health facilities 2. Supporting 1,500 girls at risk of FGM/C in the 7 villages 3. Providing access to clean water for over 3,000 people in 7 villages. 4. Supporting 7 villages (Shompole, Kilonito, Maparasha, Meto, Kiloh, Olenarau and Olgulului) to become ODF and FGM/C free communities. 5. Attaching a trained CHW to each village to monitor and report all forms of violence against women and girls including FGM/C, domestic violence and Early Child and Forced Marriages (CEFM). By the end of the project we aim to meet the following objectives: 1. To improve infection prevention and control (IPC) among the target group(s). 2. To reduce cases of FGM/C, early marriage and teenage pregnancy among targeted communities 3. To increase acceptance and support for the C-ARP model by cultural and political leaders. 4. To generate evidence, share lessons learnt and best practices for ending FGM/C, early marriage and teenage pregnancy.

title.narrative: Kibera Reach 90 Project

title.narrative: Stop the Spread COVID-19, Kenya

description.narrative: The project will train 2,000 HCPs and 4,500 CHWs

This project aims to train community health workers (CHWs) and healthcare professionals (HCPs) using Amref's mobile digital platforms (LEAP and JIBU) on a MoH approved curriculum for COVID-19. This covers key relevant topics such as home-based care and monitoring tools (for CHWs) and infection, prevention, control measures and rapid response for COVID-19 (for HCPs).
The project also aims to support mental health initiatives including a mental health training manual and key messages.
This project is part of Amref's co-ordinated response to Stop the Spread and Flatten the Curve in 8 priority countries across Africa.

title.narrative: Empowering communities to challenge FGM and prevent COVID-19 in Gabiley

description.narrative:
This project aims to replicate the successful approaches of FGM prevention projects previously supported by the Adelman Foundation, and combine COVID-19 prevention messaging to ensure the wide range of community representatives involved in challenging FGM are also able to share lifesaving information on COVID-19.
The COVID-19 prevention activities will reach 16,000 households, directly benefitting approximately 96,000 people. By supporting Somaliland’s efforts to reduce the spread and impact of COVID-19, we hope to strengthen our FGM programme. The FGM component of this project will directly benefit 1,208 people living in rural communities of Gabiley District, indirectly benefitting tens of thousands more through the sharing of information and influencing up to 20,000 people through media programmes.

title.narrative: Emergency Assistance to the households severely affected by floods 2020 in Chandpur district

description.narrative:
In August 2020 at least 5.49 million people of 1,057 unions of 160 upazilas in 33 Districts of north, north-eastern and middle parts of Bangladesh were flooded due to heavy monsoon downpour and overflowing of rivers.
CB are proposing a 3 month project (August 15, 2020 to November 14, 2020) to provide Unconditional Multi-purpose Cash Grants (MPCG), distribution of hygiene kits and awareness raising sessions on COVID-19 and hygiene promotion targeting 3,288 people located in remote areas of Chandpur district. CB has targeted the most affected families in terms of loss of livelihood and shelter due to the riverbank erosion.
The impact of the 2020 Monsoon floods on affected communities is especially severe and complex - given the prolonged inundation and complications arising from the COVID-19 pandemic. Social distancing and hand-washing are almost impossible to maintain as flood affected people are displaced and evacuating to congested shelters where WASH facilities are also compromised. Losses of income caused by COVID-19 make it even harder for families to recover.

title.narrative: Vocational training and entrepreneurship support to support marginalised families (Phase-2).

description.narrative:
This project aims to improve the income, livelihoods and living conditions of the most disadvantaged and marginalised people, including women, indigenous people and people living with disabilities. This project will work with 125 people, of which 75 men and 50 women, including people with disabilities and other vulnerable groups, to support them to diversify their income, livelihoods and learn new skills which can help them to earn an income in the future.
This will be achieved through: - Improved technical skills for young people, allowing them to develop sustainable livelihoods or long-term future employment. - Decreased levels of discrimination towards people living with disability as PWDs are seen as equal members of the family and are able to generate an income.
The proposed working area is 87 villages of four unions (Nilganj, Dalbuganj, Mithaganj, Tiakhali) under Kalapara Upazila of Patuakhali District in Bangladesh. The total population of the proposed working areas are 65,869 (32,445 men and 33,424 women).
The learning from the first phase of the Vastenactie/CB project will be incorporated into Phase 2, such as the COVID-19 health and safety measures practiced through trainings being split into 10 students per class as well as PPE being obligatory in each lesson. CB will also maintain their relationships with local government throughout the second phase of the project.
The Proyash project is a 3-year CAFOD funded project with Caritas Bangladesh and ADD Bangladesh, working to support the most marginalised, particularly women and people living with disability, to practice agroecology techniques and develop sustainable livelihoods. Vastenactie’s support, helps to complement this project through working in the same geographical location to provide tailored vocational training to these vulnerable groups.

title.narrative: Support to Bolivian prisoners and migrants with food and hygiene supplies

description.narrative: To date Bolivia has over 500 confirmed cases of COVID19 but is achieving very low levels of testing and the healthcare system is very weak, almost non-existent in rural areas. The government's strict quarantine response began on 21st March and remains in force to try to stem transmission. The rules allow people to go out to buy food one morning a week and driving is prohibited unless authorised. These rules are causing extreme hardship for migrants, the prison population, elderly people in care homes, orphanages and communities of indigenous peoples in cities. Pastoral Social Caritas Bolivia (PSCB) will provide food and hygiene supplies to Bolivian prisoners and migrants (national and international) in La Paz, Oruro and Potosi with within a framework of respect and dignity of people’s basic rights during the coronavirus health crisis. The resources will support two vulnerable groups: a) people deprived of their liberty (1,696 people) and b) national and international migrants in the cities of La Paz, Oruro and Potosi (300 people) totalling approximately 1996 people. Food rations and hygiene essentials will be purchased and delivered by the PSCB diocese teams based in each city. These teams are made up of staff and volunteers. The food rations will provide one meal per day for five days in the prisons in addition to hygiene products including toilet paper and hand sanitiser. As prisons are closed to visitors, the food will be delivered to the prison kitchens. Monitoring will be done by signoff and photos of all including prison staff, prisoners and the PSCB team. Migrant families, including Venezuelan refugees, are living in temporary shelters from houses to bus terminals. The food rations will provide one meal per day for 14 days for this vulnerable groups who will also receive hygiene products and essential medicine when possible. PSCB is receiving support from other agencies to provide support to other prisons and to support other vulnerable groups

title.narrative: COVID support to indigenous campesino families in the Curva, Mocomoco y Ancoraimes municipalities

description.narrative: Bolivia is experiencing a catastrophic situation, with COVID arriving on the back of violent widespread social upheaval at the end of 2019. The country went into strict quarantine in March, which has not been respected by many due to partisan political interests peddling disinformation. Blockaders protesting the delays to the national elections are hampering the delivery of oxygen and essential medical products. Many families have been plunged into a food security crisis. They continue to face a scarcity or absence of food and due to the quarantine restrictions, they have been unable to access the state bonds which would have provided desperately needed income. The families in rural areas supported by Fundacion Nuna have been able to survive on existing agricultural products, however they are currently suffering from shortages of seeds, dry food products and other non-food items which if not resolved quickly will exacerbate the food crisis in both rural communities and in the urban areas that rely on locally-produced food. The current social unrest which is likely to continue and worsen during September and October is also their access to markets and options for earning income to buy seeds. Fundacion Nuna will provide seeds to indigenous campesino families located in 16 communities across three municipalities, Curva, Mocomoco and Ancoraimes in the La Paz department. Nuna will also carry out much needed awareness raising about COVID 19 and safety practices and provide PPE for families in the target communities. The team will coordinate with community authorities to prioritise support to the most vulnerable community members including elderly men and women who have been abandoned by their families, families led by women, families with large numbers of children.

title.narrative: Emergency Support for the Indigenous People of Roraima Against COVID-19

description.narrative:
Over 514,992 cases of COVID-19 have been confirmed in Brazil, making it the country with the 2nd highest number of infections in the world. Over 206,000 people have recovered from the disease and over 29,000 people have died. As only half a million tests have been carried out, scientists estimate these numbers to be under-estimated by a factor of 15, meaning that 5.6 million infections and 345,000 deaths likely. The Amazon region has been particularly badly hit, with health infrastructure being completely overwhelmed by the end of April 2020. There have been grave concerns for the survival of indigenous communities, and campaigners have declared that unless action is taken, we will witness a genocide.
This project will have two lines of action. Firstly, ISA will support two ethnic groups to self-isolate in the forest for up to 3 months to protect themselves against the spread of COVID 19. These groups are the Wai Wai and the Yanomami. The Yanomami will remain in the forest for two to three months living off forest food and fishing plus some processed food (which will be provided by ISA) to secure basic nutrition. The Wai Wai families will travel to areas in the forest where they usually harvest Brazil nuts (the harvest runs from the end of May until August). This will provide them with additional livelihoods options, post-pandemic. The third group to benefit from this project are Macuxi, Wapichana and Taurepang people with support going to acquisition of COVID tests and PPE to indigenous communities based in Eastern Roraima who have constructed sanitary barriers at the exit and entrance of communities. The other line of action is to carry on providing accurate information about the Covid to the communities and ensuring information from the communities are reported to the authorities (FUNAI and SESAI) in case of COVID infection and threats such as illegal mining and logging in their territories.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Emergency Response: Life on the streets in São Paulo - solidarity and resistance (Grito)

description.narrative: By the end of July 2020 Brazil had over 2.4 million confirmed Coronavirus cases and near 90,000 deaths, with 0.5 million in São Paulo (SP) alone and 21,000 deaths. Cases continued to rise as the country reopens. Health services were reportedly near to collapse and 58% of recorded deaths occurring at home. The number of street homeless is likely to be in excess of the official figure of 24,000 people due to the economic impacts of COVID-19. This group is at high risk of direct and indirect impacts of COVID-19 due to difficulties self-isolating, prevalence of pre-existing health conditions including respiratory illness, poor nutrition, drug and alcohol problems, and difficulties in accessing health and social protection services, including COVID emergency benefits. This project will provide emergency relief (non-food items), advocacy and accompaniment to access services to ensure that street homeless people survive the crisis and can maintain their dignity, are able to access longer-term support and can influence government actions and programmes that affect them. The project will provide life-saving support to 3000 street homeless people in central São Paulo through provision of hygiene kits, sleeping bags and tents, accompaniment to access health and social protection policies, and referrals to other services. Information about the needs of street homeless people will be shared with duty-bearers at local and subnational government via the PopRua government-civil society dialogue mechanism, thus benefiting street homeless people across the city.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Emergency Response: health accompaniment to vulnerably housed people in São Paulo

description.narrative: By the end of July 2020 Brazil had over 2.4 million confirmed Coronavirus cases and near 90,000 deaths, with 0.5 million in São Paulo (SP) alone and 21,000 deaths. Cases continued to rise as the country reopens. Health services were reportedly near to collapse and 58% of recorded deaths occurring at home. The 2 million people living in favelas and poor peri-urban communities, have been disproportionately affected with research showing that residents of the poorest districts of São Paulo are 10 times more likely to die of COVID than those in wealthier neighbourhoods. Lack of economic options, crowded conditions, poor ventilation and lack of basic sanitation have made it difficult to follow guidelines. Poorer access to and quality of health care, higher pre-existing risk factors, and lack of reliable information have contributed to poorer outcomes. Low paid workers have lost their jobs and many have no money to buy food. Government emergency benefits (about half a minimum salary) have been difficult to access for many of the poorest. This project will provide life-saving support with health, nutrition, information and protection needs to 24,978 people living in 26 informal occupations of land and buildings through the following interventions: provision of health accompaniment to 3,300 families to reduce their vulnerability to COVID-19 and ensure appropriate signposting to health services and treatment; provision of accurate information about the virus; accompaniment to access social protection policies; strengthening of 43 local solidarity committees involved in distribution of donations of food and hygiene to 6,600 families; prevention, referrals and emergency support for survivors of gender-based violence; advocacy to prevent evictions and ensure vulnerable people are not left without shelter; information sharing with duty-bearers about the needs of vulnerable groups during the crisis.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Emergency Response: food and hygiene provision to favela communities in São Paulo

description.narrative:
By the end of July 2020 Brazil had over 2.4 million confirmed Coronavirus cases and near 90,000 deaths, with 0.5 million in São Paulo (SP) alone and 21,000 deaths. Cases continued to rise as the country reopens. Health services were reportedly near to collapse and 58% of recorded deaths occurring at home. The 2 million people living in favelas and poor peri-urban communities have been disproportionately affected with research showing that residents of the poorest districts of São Paulo are 10 times more likely to die of COVID than those in wealthier neighbourhoods. Lack of economic options, crowded conditions, poor ventilation and lack of basic sanitation have made it difficult to follow guidelines. Poorer access to and quality of health care, higher pre-existing risk factors, and lack of reliable information have contributed to poorer outcomes in São Paulo's favelas. Low paid workers have lost their jobs, government emergency benefits are half of the minimum wage and many have been unable to access, or had difficulties accessing them.
This project will benefit 10,528 people in 8 favela communities in eastern São Paulo with improved access to information about the virus and how to prevent it, signposting to social protection, health, and gender-based violence support services. 2,820 of the most vulnerable people will receive food and hygiene kits for 3 months. 548 people will benefit from increased household income through participation in a recycling project which will also benefit the whole favela with reduced flood and vector borne disease risk. The 8 favela communities targeted by the project will also benefit from advocacy for street cleaning to reduce COVID and other disease risk.

title.narrative: Phase 2 - HAY Ye'kuana and Sanoma Emergency COVID-19 response

description.narrative:
Brazil is in a second wave of COVID-19 with the highest number of weekly cases since mid-August with 6.6 million confirmed cases of COVID-19 (6,603,540) and 176,941 deaths, the 2nd highest number of deaths in the world. Isolated indigenous groups living in the Brazilian Amazon are among the most vulnerable, due to lack of access to adequate health care and low immunity to external diseases.
This project aims to: a) decrease the risk of COVID-19 of isolated indigenous groups in TIY (Yanomami Territory) in the Amazon by avoiding travel outside their communities and improve nutrition and life conditions, through the distribution of food, tools and clothing; and b) ensure access to education, healthcare, and the means to communicate threats (via radio) within their communities via guaranteeing access to solar energy systems in schools, health posts and radio, to support self-sustainable living and avoid external exposure to COVID-19. It intends to reach a total of 3,574 people from 31 communities located in the Auaris region, of which 26 communities (2,961 people) are Sanöma, and 5 are Ye´kuana, reaching 613 people.
The main activities are: a) the distribution of food/non-food/hygiene kits to 31 communities located in Auaris, and the installation of 5 solar panels in 5 communities - 3 Sanoma communities: Kalisi, Kolulu and Polasai, and 2 Ye'kuana communities: Fuduuwaduinha e Kuratanha. The Auaris region was chosen because it is the region in Yanomami Territory with the highest demographic density, with more than 3,500 people registering only 9 cases of community transmission of COVID-19, the other 63 cases were in health units in Boa Vista, the majority of cases registered by DSEI-YY on 13/11/20 occurred at CASAI - Indigenous Health Unit in Boa Vista. The installation of solar panels will supply clean energy in community spaces far away from the main landing strip where the Brazilian army barracks are located and the risk of infection with COVID-19 is higher.

title.narrative: Humanitarian aid for immediate assistance to hospitalised patients of Covid19 in Amazonas State

description.narrative:
This emergency project aims to contribute to the life-saving efforts of municipal hospitals that are treating COVID-19 patients in 4 municipalities in Amazonas state, Brazil: Tefé, Itacoatiara, Alto Solimões e Coari. It forms part of the campaign, “Amazonas and Roraima count on your solidarity”, launched by the National Bishops Conference (Northern Region I), on January 15, 2021. The objective of this campaign is to raise funds for the purchase of oxygen tanks/cylinders, PPE and other health supplies to be used in municipal hospitals in the region due to a chronic lack of capacity to store and provide oxygen, and other PPE and equipment in the Brazilian national public health system, SUS. The tanks are important because they are rechargeable at a low cost, can be reused for other patients, and will be permanent assets to smaller hospitals outside the main city of Manaus. This project will purchase 160 rechargeable oxygen tanks in Belo Horizonte, transport and safely store them in Manaus, consult with the Health Secretariats of each municipality on which hospital has the greatest need, before accompanying the respective municipal government agencies to deliver them to the relevant municipal hospital.
The spread of the new coronavirus Amazon variant in Manaus and neighbouring municipalities has led to record numbers of deaths, hospitalisations and confirmed cases of Covid-19. In January 2021, the state experienced chaos from lack of oxygen in hospitals, and as a result, 2,522 people died from Covid-19 in Amazonas. Cemeteries in the capital registered rows of hearses and had to re-install cold rooms. The demand for hospital oxygen in public hospitals in Amazonas has exceeded the daily average consumption by more than 11 times. On 2/2/21 there were 2,460 new cases of Covid-19, totalling 271,177 cases in Amazonas, of which: confirmed cases include: Coari (8.833); Itacoatiara (4.470). Deaths reported so far: Itacoatiara (179); Coari (155); Tefé (131).

title.narrative: Protection Fund for community leaders and other HRDs made vulnerable by the Covid-19 pandemic

description.narrative: Even before the pandemic Colombia was the country with most HRDs killed worldwide. In the context of the pandemic social leaders and human rights defenders have become even more vulnerable as measures imposed by the Colombian government reduce movement and they were confined to their homes, there has been a particular impact on indigenous and other rural leaders. Many of those killed or threatened are from Putumayo, Valle del Cauca, Meta, Antioquia, Santander, Córdoba, Caquetá, and at national level; a clear example of the emergency is evidenced in the number of homicides against ex-combatants, that until now exceeded 190. This project seeks to contribute to the improvement of the integral protection of human rights defenders and victims of the armed conflict, socio-political violence and territorial conflicts, providing measures to protect the life and integrity of human rights defenders and their families, as well as victims of the armed conflict, socio-political violence and territorial conflicts, which have intensified due to the pandemic situation

title.narrative: Hurricane Iota and asociated emergency response Colombia

description.narrative: More than a quarter million of people living in Colombia were affected by the tropical storm which turned into category 5 Hurricane Iota hitting the Colombia archipelago of San Andres in November 2020. Rains associated to the tropical storm turned it into a large-scale emergency affecting 25 out of 32 departments in Colombia. SNPS/Caritas Colombiana is leading a coordinated response which will include a response in Choco Department where this emergency comes on to top of the ongoing armed conflict, as well as Cartagena where 70% of the city had been flooded. They are aiming to support 12.000 people over 9 months, prioritised groups include children, pregnant women and women with small children, older adults and people with disabilities (this will depend on level of funds raised). Components include WASH (hygiene kits, access to clean water) and COVID prevention, shelter, NFI and food among others. COVID prevention measures and information sharing will also be important components.

title.narrative: Strengthening pastoral processes in peace building, human rights and care for Our Common Home -IFI

description.narrative: COVID has affected Colombia significantly and the pandemic, as well as the measures in response have exacerbated underlying issues, including having an impact the economic and socio-political stability. This project seeks to strengthen a coordinated response under the leadership of SNPS-Caritas Colombia, working together with four Church Provinces and Ecclesiastical Jurisdictions (EJ). Project participants will engage in research, training and advocacy-including communication- related to peace and reconciliation, protection of human rights and care for the common home.

title.narrative: Strengthening the capacity of partner on current context

description.narrative: Monitoring is a primarily responsibility of Partners as they are the one responsible for the implementing and monitoring projects on ground. In the current context, it is important to re-visit partners' ways of working in consideration of the current context. Partners need to remain keen about important aspects that are related to safeguarding and how to remain sensitive while implementing various interventions in the COVID context. This will also help to train partner on quality targeting and the use of IT as we adjust into the current ways of working. This will also facilitate the process of revising key aspects related to safeguarding of which, now need to be revisited with each partners and assess their implementation in how this is being applied and reflected in their day to day ways of working.

title.narrative: Supporting the CENCO's advocacy initiative

description.narrative: In response to the ongoing contextual challenge in the country, CENCO has renewed its efforts and has initiated a series of advocacy activities in Rome, Brussels, EU etc . The next steps of this mission (if the means and agenda of the President of CENCO allow them) will be in Berlin, London, Washington and New York. There is need to lobby now so that the DRC already starts to prepare for the next elections by demanding: the reform of the electoral law, the organic law governing the CENI, the reform of the Constitutional Court, the creation of a genuine civil registry file by the census of the population; it will also be a way to put a definitive end to the dangerous debate of national registration. As part of its mission and at the request of the President of CENCO, the CEJP is preparing an important advocacy mission to the European Parliament to meet Ms ARENA, Chairperson of the Parliamentary Committee on Human Rights. This advocacy will target the security situation in Ituri, North and South Kivu.The mission will include 3 steps:One. National advocacy with members of the government and accredited diplomatic missions in Kinshasa Two. Preparation of the advocacy file with the CDJP: Goma, Bukavu, Beni-Butembo and Uvira in Bukavu, a CEJP team will travel to Bukavu to also participate in the relaunch of the Peace to the Great Lakes campaign" 3. Advocacy mission to Brussels is also aligned led by The President of CENCO (Father Nshole and Father Clement). During this stage, the delegation will meet with European parliamentarians, the Belgian cabinet of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Belgian associations and the Congolese diaspora as well as the international press). The findings of this mission will be presented to the Standing Committee of Bishops in February 2020. Four degrees. Advocacy mission in Berlin (April 2020). Given the difficult time the world is going through because of the COVID19 pandemic, apart from those pleas, CENCO is also raising awareness among the Congolese population to fight against Covid 19 in the DRC. To implement this, Cenco is requesting resources to support the effectiveness of these aligned activities and support the logistics of the activities.

title.narrative: Economic Assistance to Vulnerable Families in Kinshasa during the COVID 19 Outbreak

description.narrative: COVID-19 is having a significant impact on the global economy, and for cities like Kinshasa, the impact will be more severe, where casual labour and small businesses are a lifeline for many families who are already struggling to survive.The consequence of limiting or even closing businesses in Kinshasa will have an extremely negative effect on people’s means of survival, more so than the impact of the virus being contracted, experts have warned of the dire impact this could have on many families. People will be faced with an unenviable choice of staying at home and losing much needed income, or going out to try to secure an income and potentially spread the virus or increase their risk of contracting it. The economic consequences on vulnerable families will be catastrophic in Kinshasa where many low-income families live in informal settlements and slums which make social distancing impossible. Many will be ill-served by measures that rely on the stockpiling of food, the availability of savings, the ability to work from home and the need to keep distance even from close relatives. In these environments, staying at home will itself be a risk as people live in cramped, poorly ventilated dwellings housing in large numbers, queuing to use shared toilets, drawing water from shared wells and using crowded public transport. Immediate help is needed to support vulnerable groups, particularly those working in the informal sector who can no longer access livelihoods (decreasing purchasing power and leaving them unable to buy food or basic items to help practice good hygiene and not further spread the virus), people living with disabilities, the elderly, the chronically ill, and child headed households. Alongside this immediate need for support, there is also a need for mass education campaigns to dispel myths and rumours spreading about COVID-19 and to inform on best practices.

participating-org.narrative: Union de Jeunes Congolais pour le Changement

receiver-org.narrative: Union de Jeunes Congolais pour le Changement

title.narrative: Women support to strenghten Community engagement against Corona

description.narrative: Having left China in 2019, the Corona virus, because of interactions with the whole world, is now widespread everywhere and in all countries of the World. Developed and powerful countries with a more efficient health system are today facing severe tests with overwhelmed hospitals, medical materials and equipment taken care of often limited, obviously their efforts tend towards a relative control of the disease. However, this shows that for poor countries, there is a fear of a rather dramatic situation inasmuch as the means available to these countries remain very limited and the health system there remains almost weak, extremely dependent on external aid. The DRC, in its current context, is one of those countries that need help to overcome this challenge. Confronted since10 March with a first confirmed case, the situation of CORONA VIRUS is only going up on a cruise with now more than a hundred cases and more than a dozen deaths already recorded in less than a month. Despite the alarm cries launched by the WHO and the Western media, on social networks, we continue to read a lot of bad information that the new Virus is not a reality or that blacks would not be affected by COVID 19 or by other allegations of all kinds from charlatansi in various remote areas of the country, this false information. Through this project, Centre Olame wants to sensitize the population of Bukavu city and around to be aware of the existence of this pandemic. At the end, they will take preventive measures seriously to protect themselves and others.

title.narrative: Preparing Communities to Fight Against COVID-19 and Provide Economic Support to most Vulnerable

description.narrative: This project will raise awareness on the danger of COVID-19, support communities with WASH activities and conduct protection activities. The project will be implemented in North Kivu and South Kivu provinces. The cities in these provinces are particularly fragile and challenging urban context, marked by the long-term gaps in state services, corruption, high rates of unemployment, poverty and inequality, and daily insecurity. Most of these provinces have been the theater of instabilities and intertribal conflicts for many years and host many displaced. In the best of times, the majority of those living in these provinces exercise multiple and creative forms of débrouille (resourcefulness) to survive on a day to-day basis. Many are street-venders; they are classified into walking vendors, (porters, vegetable sellers and sellers of bread, cakes and pastries, etc.), and fixed vendors (battery and tyre repairers, mechanics and cobblers, etc.). the provinces also have a huge majority of those who relay on agriculture for their survival. Rumours around COVID–19 abound as the national and provincial government has not communicated clearly about symptoms or prevention, information provided is confused and/or contradictory. In addition, with rumours that COVID-19 vaccine may be tested in DRC, many have become skeptical and believe the pandemic has been imported and the government is playing to gain international attention. Immediate help is needed to sensitize the communities and support vulnerable groups economically, particularly the most vulnerable who rely on informal sector, people living with disabilities, the elderly, the chronically ill, and child headed households. Alongside this immediate need for support, there is also a need to communicate best practices relating to prevention and mitigation and for a mass education campaigns to dispel myths and rumours spreading about COVID-19.

title.narrative: Support to the National Episcopal Conference of Congo in communication material

description.narrative: The world is currently going through a dramatic moment due to the Covid 19 pandemic. It is since March 10 that this pandemic has been declared in DRC, specifically in Kinshasa. Two weeks later, there were border closures and stopping of flights to the various provinces. Until now, the mobility of people from one province to another is still prohibited and means of transport are not yet authorized to circulate from one province to another. Even in the case of the reopening of these borders, the procedure will be in order for the movement of people in order to avoid a wide contagion, especially for people of an advanced age. With the restrictions associated with covid-19, the Bishops are unable to meet face to face. It is for this reason that CENCO approached CAFOD to ask for its support. This project aims to support CENCO with some communication materials to facilitate them to communicate virtually by video conference.

title.narrative: Improvement of the socio-economic living conditions of women/girls and their families in 30 parishes

description.narrative:
The project contributes to significantly reduce the violence caused by wars and armed conflicts and to help households beneficiaries to develop psychological and economic resilience mechanisms.
Four results must be achieved for the success of this project, namely: - In 30 parishes of the Archdiocese of Bukavu, resilience mechanisms have been established to cope with the trauma and vulnerability of women/girls and their families, particularly combating all kinds of gender-based violence; - Gender-based domestic violence is addressed and thanks to sociotherapy from listening centers and grassroots groups, the number of conflicts within households has been reduced. - The income situation of the families supported by the project has improved. - The project contributes to the prevention of the spread of Covid-19 and strengthens the resilience of the populations of twelve parishes in the face of income losses linked to the coronavirus.
During the project realization, sociotherapy remains a central aspect that links psycho-social support to the orientation towards self-determination and increased income for women and girls. This project contribute to CAFOD strategic vision to end violence against women and strengthen the economic justice to fight poverty.

title.narrative: Multisectoral emergency assistance to the most vulnerable people affected by storms in Kalole

description.narrative: Through the distribution of unconditional cash, this project will empower the community as we will do a survey prior to the cash distribution to assess the power dynamic within HHs and carry out sensitisation around targeting, especially as it will be largely women who will be receiving the cash on behalf of the HHs. Priority will be given to the most vulnerable households affected by the storms and wind, including widowed women, children heads of households, elderly people, people with disabilities, chronically ill, and / or other people who are unable to buy food and goods of their choice that meet the need of their households. The targeting criteria will be included within the sensitisation to ensure the do no harm principle is adhered to. The targeting criteria will also be informed by a tool developed through a recent Start Fund Learning Grant (see section 2.3 below for more information). We will organize the mobile banking through which each household will receive £114.50. The head of the household will receive the cash for the HH. This amount has been advised by the NFI cluster group. Throughout the project, we will take into account the COVID-19 prevention measures as stated by the government and include COVID-19 sensitisation activities which will reach 10,932 people. The vulnerabilities of certain groups will be taken into consideration. For example, to avoid pregnant women, the elderly and people living with disabilities standing for too long, beneficiary lists will be categorised in order for them to quickly recognise their names. The cash will be done through mobile money which means people will not have to wait in long queues to receive their cash. Queues will also be socially distanced. CAFOD and Caritas Kasongo will target 972 households (5,832 individuals) with unconditional cash, among them: 850 of those affected directly by the storm and 122 of the host families affected by the current crisis, especially in the city of Penekusu and Kiloza, Mwamba, Nyalugungu, Nsamba, Wasezya, Ndenge, and Kalole villages in Kalole health zone. This represents respectively 70% of 1215 direct affected HH and 5% of 607 host families to ensure "Do No Harm" is taken into consideration. Beneficiaries will be selected and targeted by the Caritas Development Kasongo team in collaboration with the disaster committee, the representative of the humanitarian affairs division, local authorities and members of the Basic Humanitarian Committees (CHB) on the basis of the vulnerability criteria mentioned above which will be validated by all stakeholders, including the community, during the evaluation. In terms of coordination, we have already coordinated with Christian-Aid and we will continue to cooperate with the other local authorities throughout the implementation.

title.narrative: Supporting survivors of sexual violence and their families in South Kivu, DRC

description.narrative: The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has long been devastated by war and violence. Dozens of illegal armed groups have been responsible for endless human rights abuses and widespread insecurity. Sexual and gender-based violence have become defining characteristics of the conflict, a tactic of war. Fuelled and motivated by Congo’s minerals, rebel and army forces are inclined to maintain an insecure environment that ensures the continuation of the status quo. Despite intervention by the international community, the eastern zone of the DRC, including South Kivu, where this project is based, remains extremely fragile. Several armed groups continue to create fear amongst communities. Responsible women who walk many miles to collect water and food, are at risk of being attacked several times. The effects of rape and other forms of violence against women go beyond physical suffering and disabilities; they also compromise the psychological health and social life of the women for the rest of their lives. Many of those who have experienced sexual violence remain silent, for fear of being rejected by their families and communities. This project has been identified with the involvement of parish priests, PSA’s, community leaders, project participants, staffs of CDJP partner and local authorities. The desire of the project participants which is to expand their enterprises has been taken into consideration during the development of this next phase. There is huge potential for certain enterprises in the area, including bee keeping because most of the honey consumed locally is brought in from Rwanda. CAFOD has funded an initial study into the potential for beekeeping that the project will build upon. The overall goal of this project is to contribute to the community recovery and recovery of human dignity of people from six parishes in South Kivu, DRC. It will be done by working to achieve the following outcomes: (1)Strengthening the managerial and technical capacity of 300 people; (2) Supporting the victims of rape and their families; (3) Raising awareness of key issues by training 300 participants on environmental protection (tree planting, management of rubbish, efficient use of natural pesticides etc), as championed by Pope Francis in Laudato Si, as well as on protection measures against Coronavirus.

We will organize the mobile banking through which each household will receive £58.14. The head of the household will receive the cash for the HH. title.narrative: Multisectoral emergency assistance to the most vulnerable people affected by storms in Salamabila r

description.narrative: The expected impact of this intervention is the reduction of suffering by improving the living conditions of the beneficiaries as they will access food, NFI, shelter, etc. The cash that beneficiaries will receive will allow them to buy essential household items and/or rent houses. This will allow them to be sheltered from the weather and reduce the likelihood of becoming sick. HHs will as likely be able to access at least two meals per day and repsond to other needs. The project will empower the community as we will do a survey prior to the cash distribution to assess the power dynamic within HHs and carry out sensitisation where needed, especially as it will be largely women who will be receiving the cash on behalf of the HHs. Priority will be given to the most vulnerable households affected by the storms and wind, including widowed women, children heads of households, elderly people, people with disabilities, chronically ill, and / or other people who are unable to buy food and goods of their choice that meet the need of their households. We will organize the mobile banking through which each affecte household will receive £147.28 and the host families will receive £58.14, the head of the household will receive the cash for the HH. This amount has been advised by the Food security and NFI/shelter clusters groups. Throughout the project, we will take into account the vulnerabilities of certain groups. For example, in order to avoid pregnant women, the elderly and people living with disabilities standing for too long, beneficiary lists will be categorised in order for them to quickly recognise their names. The cash will be done through mobile money which means people will not have to wait in long queues to receive their cash. It is expected that this project will enable people to meet their basic need including food, NFI/shelter, etc. CAFOD and Caritas Kasongo will target 520 HH (3120 people) with the cash and 12240 people with the awareness raising on COVID-19. Feedback and complaints mechanisms will be put in place in the affected communities . CAFOD/Caritas Kasogo's safeguarding principles will be explained to all in the affected communities (Kindu, Kama, Byenge, Du marche and Namoya).

title.narrative: Emergency assistance for most vulnerable Households affected by the crisis in Eringeti

description.narrative: According to the Eringeti IDPs committee, there are 1,300 new displaced households in Eringeti who arrived from October 17 to 20, 2020. It is reported that some families are spending the night in low-income houses abandoned by local populations, others in host families, very unfortunately these families have the same poverty lines as the displaced and others in local churches, but others are completely homeless. These displaced people are exposed to bad weather and mosquito bites. They are without food, essential household items, toilets, etc. They are exposed to problems of malnutrition, SGBV protection, water-borne diseases, COVID-19, etc. Local authorities are not equipped to face this emergency and provide support to the affected population. Up to now, most of affected people haven’t received any assistance yet and it is highly unlikely they will receive any. Local authorities are not equipped to face this emergency and provide support to the affected population. Up to now, most of affected people haven’t received any assistance yet and it is highly unlikely they will receive any. According to the Preliminary Diagnosis Report carried out by the displaced persons committee, displaced persons need: - Food security: All displaced households are in need of food, some had spent their first night without eating and others benefited from the generosity of host families to find something to eat, although without being full. Displaced households without everything do not have the resources to obtain food from the local market. The indigenous populations painfully following the lack of access to the fields, the only source of income. - Shelters / AME. The newly displaced are living in host families, in close proximity, and abandoned houses without essential household items. These families, having traveled several kilometers before reaching Eringeti, are deprived of everything and are exposed to the elements. - Protection. Some of the displaced were showing signs of trauma, crying and not knowing how to speak with the mission team. There is a need for protection actors to organize an in-depth protection assessment mission, in order to identify the protection problems and risks for these newly displaced persons. Some children are said to be separated from their families, while searching towards Eringeti. 30 unaccompanied children are also reported in this locality.

title.narrative: Supporting the ACEAC-CENCO Bishops’ advocacy mission in Eastern DRC

description.narrative: The ACEAC’ mission, as a socio-pastoral action platform of all Catholic Churches in the Great Lakes Sub-region, crosses the borders of nations, tribes, ethnicities and languages, and according to its Statutes,). It aims to be "a forum for exploring ways and means of promoting dialogue and concertation, mutual assistance and ecclesial cooperation among affiliated Episcopal Conferences for the in-depth evangelisation of people in Africa in their cultural, social and religious environment. In Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, recurrent insecurity is a feature of this region, with inter-ethnic and cross-border rebellion conflicts. Indeed, several people have died there in savage massacres. Since 2014, there are 4000 people reported killed in the Diocese of Beni-Butembo alone. And as misfortune never comes alone, the region has been shaken by the Ebola virus epidemic which has caused more than 2000 deaths, while the Covid-19 continues to spread. As a result, the population of eastern DRCongo complains of being abandoned by the international and even national community. Indeed, Mgr Melchisédech Sikuli, Bishop of Butembo-Beni echoed this in his interview with the newspaper Forum des As on 6 November 2020. He castigated the revolting indifference towards the massacres of the population (cf. Forum des As n° 6279 of Friday, November 6, 2020, p. 8). Mgr Melchisédech Sikuli had voiced the same cry of alarm during the CENCO Plenary Assembly (October 2020). This project intends to advocate for enabling peace in eastern DRC on behalf of affected communities, to gather information on the ground to nourish advocacy action and to undertake and refresh relationship with various stakeholders.

title.narrative: Youth Engagement for Peace and stability forum

description.narrative: In the North Kivu province and much of eastern DRC, the situation is still affected by insecurity and political instability, combined with ethnic conflicts, armed group activism and wars that have serious consequences on the living conditions of the population, youth unemployment and illiteracy. Governance problems in the DRC at all levels with its corollaries such as corruption, impunity, poor management of public resources, a lack of trust between ethnic communities, a leadership and confidence gap between young people and leaders exacerbate the limited involvement of young people in the democratic space and limit their participation as citizens. Many youths are faced unemployment and are exploited by political leaders. Others are recruited into armed groups and this increase harm in most disadvantaged communities in North-Kivu Province. Supporting this project expects to increase youth’s peace and citizenship awareness, to reduce ethnic and political manipulation and provide opportunities for youth to become change agents, and to engage in peace work and governance as key actors in nonviolent way. Project also expects empowering young people as genuine actors for change and peace in the region, informing them and raising their awareness as to their role and responsibility for building peace and political stability within the country. The project plans to organize music festival and cultural activities as well as open space and workshops on topics related to Peacebuilding, leadership, entrepreneurship, civic and democratic participation, communication and dialog mechanism to build relationship as well as raising awareness in preventing and dealing with the corona virus pandemic (COVID-19). Faith leaders and key persons from local civil society and officials will mentor, share experiences and best practices with youths during the forum. Project activities will be cofounded by Goma’Diocese and implemented by CDJP Goma' staff and “Maison des Jeunes” with support from CAFOD peace building program Officer. The youth peace forum will be held in Goma and will bring together about 15000 youths from Goma Diocese and neighbouring dioceses.

participating-org.narrative: Commission Diocésaine Justice et Paix du Diocèse Goma

title.narrative: Strengthening community engagement to fight against COVID-19 in Kinshasa

description.narrative: This project will strengthen the community engagement to fight against the second wave of COVID-19 by providing clear information that counter rumours, misinformation and panics by training health personnel and community opinion leaders/Influencers and mass communication practitioners whom in turn will significantly help to populate the right information in the community and consequently impact on behavioural change of the communities. The trainings proposed by the project will be done in collaboration with the local health ministry whose delegates will facilitate the sessions. As a result of the training, the Journalists will produce adapted messages based on the materials that have already been designed by the Ministry of health and broadcast messages that speak to the context and consequently impact on the listeners’ behaviour. In the same angle, the faith and opinion leaders having been trained, they will sensitize the community members by providing accurate and articulated information since they live in the same community. The project will also strengthen the protection measures by providing 12500 masks to the most vulnerable households in Ngiri-ngiri community

title.narrative: Contributing to prevention and control of COVID-19 infection in North and South Kivu Provinces

description.narrative: The number of new cases in the DRC is continuously increasing, with a test positivity rate of 21% . COVID-19 pandemic outbreak began just as the country was winning a nearly two-year battle with Ebola which had resulted to 3,481 cases and 2,299 deaths. The number of confirmed COVID-19 cases is growing daily in DRC, and as of February 7th 2021, 23,671 people had been tested to be positive, 15,113 recovered and 681 died. Notably, on November 17th, 2020, the Ministry of Health issued an alert on a new wave of COVID-19 outbreak in DRC, while the Africa CDC warned the government to step up preparation for second wave as 19% increase of cases was noted in DRC as of October . Kinshasa, North Kivu and South Kivu are among the areas greatly affected. As of February, 7th2021, Kinshasa reported 18,575 COVID-19 cases, North Kivu reported 1,366; and South Kivu 607. With limited testing capacity and lack of access to healthcare, the number of actual cases could be far higher, and millions of lives could be lost unless the international community and civil society step up with more help.
